items.synopsis: They're integral to Australia's tourism and agriculture industries, but backpacker numbers dropped with travel restrictions during COVID-19.

title.children: Has Australia got its backpackers back? This data suggests so

image.altText: a composite image of two boys, seen from behind

items.synopsis: Brothers Kaleb and Jonathan*, then 19 and 17, were found in May 2020 after their father was discovered dead from a terminal illness at their home in Brisbane's northern suburbs.

title.children: Queensland government should apologise to teens with autism found living in filth, royal commission finds

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has announced he will leave the airline tomorrow, bringing forward his planned retirement by two months. Follow live.

title.children: Alan Joyce to leave Qantas tomorrow, bringing forward retirement by two months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ASX 200 futures: -0.3% to 7,277 points Australian dollar: flat at 64.61 cents S & P 500 : +0.2% at 4,515 points (Friday's figures) Nasdaq: flat at 14,031 (Friday's figures) FTSE: -0.2% 7,452 points EuroStoxx: -0.2% 458 points Spot gold: flat at $1,938/ounce Brent crude: +0.5% to $US89.00/barrel Iron ore : +0.5% to $US114.60/tonne Bitcoin: -0.5% $US25,734
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot 7:30AM AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder has thanked Alan Joyce for his leadership. "Alan has always had the best interests of Qantas front and centre, and today shows that. On behalf of the Board, we sincerely thank him for his leadership through some enormous challenges and for thinking well-ahead on opportunities like ultra long-haul travel. This transition comes at what is obviously a challenging time for Qantas and its people. We have an important job to do in restoring the public's confidence in the kind of company we are, and that's what the Board is focused on, and what the management under Vanessa's leadership will do."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas chair pays tribute to Alan Joyce

children.content: Qantas Chairman Richard Goyder has thanked Alan Joyce for his leadership.

"Alan has always had the best interests of Qantas front and centre, and today shows that. On behalf of the Board, we sincerely thank him for his leadership through some enormous challenges and for thinking well-ahead on opportunities like ultra long-haul travel.

This transition comes at what is obviously a challenging time for Qantas and its people. We have an important job to do in restoring the public's confidence in the kind of company we are, and that's what the Board is focused on, and what the management under Vanessa's leadership will do."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce will retire two months early. It comes after the consumer watchdog launched legal action last week alleging the airline sold 8,000 tickets for flights it had already cancelled. The airline has also been accused of bullying smaller airlines and influencing the Albanese government to block Qatar Airways from doubling its capacity into Australia. The airline has admitted its reputation has been 'hit hard on several fronts.' Alan Joyce says in the last few weeks the focus on Qantas means the company needs to move ahead with its renewal. "The best thing I can do under these circumstances is to bring forward my retirement and hand over to Vanessa and the new management team now, knowing they will do an excellent job." Alan Joyce has been CEO for the past 15 years. "There have been many ups and downs, and there is clearly much work still to be done, especially to make sure we always deliver for our customers." Vanessa Hudson will take on the top job effective tomorrow.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas boss to step down early

children.content: Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce will retire two months early.
It comes after the consumer watchdog launched legal action last week alleging the airline sold 8,000 tickets for flights it had already cancelled.
The airline has also been accused of bullying smaller airlines and influencing the Albanese government to block Qatar Airways from doubling its capacity into Australia.
The airline has admitted its reputation has been 'hit hard on several fronts.'
Alan Joyce says in the last few weeks the focus on Qantas means the company needs to move ahead with its renewal.
"The best thing I can do under these circumstances is to bring forward my retirement and hand over to Vanessa and the new management team now, knowing they will do an excellent job."
Alan Joyce has been CEO for the past 15 years.
"There have been many ups and downs, and there is clearly much work still to be done, especially to make sure we always deliver for our customers."
Vanessa Hudson will take on the top job effective tomorrow.

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce will leave Qantas after 15 years with $125 million, while the airline's operations have suffered and its reputation has been trashed. It begs the question, writes business editor Ian Verrender, will he be booted before he quits?

title.children: The never-ending spin that protected Alan Joyce and Qantas from reality has started to unravel

image.altText: A woman lies back in a chair smiling, while someone injects her forehead with a syringe.

items.synopsis: Australia's medical regulator says it is cracking down on cosmetic procedures such as botox and fillers, but those living with the long-term impacts of botched procedures say the focus has come too late.

title.children: Cosmetic surgery crackdown now targeting fillers, botox and other procedures

image.altText: A seven-month-old boy with scratches on his face and head.

items.synopsis: Seven-month-old Jack had been left alone, unsupervised, in a room when he was beaten by another child. His mother is now pursuing legal action and lawyers say their caseload of injuries sustained at childcare centres is increasing.
